answers.author: Louise Snyder
answers.text:
Peter-You might want to check out the process used by the city of Phoenix, Arizona (a participant in the ICMA Center for Performance Measurement). The city conducts public budget hearings in all council districts, where citizen feedback on the budget is collected in person. Here are links to three pages listing the city's 2010 hearing schedule and other details of the city's process:
http://phoenix.gov/budget/hearings.html
http://phoenix.gov/news/012810budget.html
http://www.phoenix.gov/budget/bud05adp.pdf
Hope this is helpful!

answers.author: Mike Cohen
answers.text:
Peter, 
An increasing number of cities across the US are using online public comment forums to encourage citizen input into their annual budget (and goals) processes. These online public comment forums have the order and decorum of conventional public hearings so they are civil, First Amendment compliant and meet public records act requirements. They also are very informative for government decision makers (as well as citizens).
Here are some examples:
Palo Alto CA:
http://www.peakdemocracy.com/portals/5/Forum_94/Issue_231?a=77
Williamsburg VA:
http://www.williamsburgva.gov/openforum
Lake Oswego OR
http://www.peakdemocracy.com/portals/55/Forum_224/Issue_347
Let me know if you want more examples of how these online public comment forums are enabling local governments to increase civic engagement, and correspondingly give citizens easy and compelling access to the interactive decision making process.
Mike
Peak Democracy Inc
510-225-5336

answers.author: Ali Miller Richards
answers.text:
Also check out the new white paper "Connected Communities" on citizen engagement and community building--including how governments can incorporate citizens into the budget process. The paper, prepared for the Alliance for Innovation by James H. Svara and Janet Denhardt, Arizona State University, is available online at http://www.transformgov.org.

author: Peter Hames
text: Is anyone using an interactive process for gaining citizen input into the annual budget process?  Interactive could be via the Web, civic engagement processes, or out-reach meetings to the community.
title: Interactive Citizen Preferences for the Budget?
